Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Tailoring Properties of Graphene by Modifying its Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
*** Non-Technical Abstract ***
Graphene, a single atomic layer of graphite, is a recently discovered material that conducts electricity better than copper, has mechanical strength greater than steel, and can be patterned into structures smaller than a virus. Due to this unique combination of properties, graphene has been hailed as a possible replacement of silicon in electronic devices. Because graphene is very conductive, electronic components made of graphene are expected to be able to operate at very high speeds while dissipating very little energy. This award supports a project that experimentally explores the fundamental reasons limiting the conductivity of graphene. In particular, this project examines how the materials near the graphene surface influence the flow of electrons in graphene. The project utilizes a combination of state-of-the-art techniques to fabricate graphene devices with nanometer dimensions and to measure the properties of these devices at low temperatures and in high magnetic fields. If successful, the project will pave the road to both designing appropriate substrates for graphene-based electronics and to creating novel graphene based devices. An integral part of this research project is to introduce underrepresented minorities into the cutting edge scientific research through the partnership with Fisk University, a historically black university. The PhD students engaged in this work will gain hands-on experience and skills in forefront scientific research that are highly valuable in careers ranging from academia to the semiconducting industry.
*** Technical Abstract ***
Because of the two-dimensional nature of graphene, its electronic and magnetic properties sensitively depend on its environment -- the substrate under the graphene, the impurities near it, and the material coating its surface. This dependence influences many of the fundamental properties of graphene, such as its minimum conductivity, and determines the material parameters, such as carrier mobility, essential for device applications. This project explores the influence of the environment on the electronic and magnetic properties of graphene by placing it onto different substrates and depositing different materials onto its surface. To understand the intrinsic electronic properties of graphene, pristine suspended graphene devices will be fabricated and the electronic transport properties of these devices will be measured at low temperature and at high magnetic fields. To elucidate the role of the charge and spin scattering due to the environment, the transport properties of suspended graphene covered with controllably deposited impurities will be studied. The project also examines the possibility of inducing magnetism in graphene by depositing magnetic materials over it and by depositing graphene onto corrugated substrates. The project supports education of graduate students pursuing a doctoral degree and includes an integrated outreach plan that introduces underrepresented minorities as well as undergraduate students into graduate level research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphene, monolayer Transition Metal Dichalcogenides (TMDs), and monolayer hexagonal Boron Nitride (hBN) are substances only a few atoms thick collectively called “two-dimensional materials” (2DM). The minute thickness of 2DMs leads to extreme environmental sensitivity of all properties of these materials. The overarching goal of this project was to investigate the physical mechanisms of this sensitivity. We discovered and explored several mechanisms through which 2DMs “talk” to their environment: 

1)    The presence of a dielectric medium on top of a 2DM leads to screening of electromagnetic interactions between charge carriers in a 2DM. We showed that the strength of charge carrier scattering in graphene can be sharply decreased by embedding graphene into an environment with high dielectric constant. In TMDs, we showed that the presence of dielectric screening distorts natural excitonic absorption features. Moreover, we discovered that the effective dielectric constant of the environment “seen” by an exciton (bound electron-hole pair) in TMDs depends on the symmetries of that exciton.

2)    The presence of ions near the surface of a 2DM leads to scattering of charge carriers and electrostatic gating of the 2DM. We developed an approach to quantify the density and surface velocity of such ions through signatures in electrical transport.

3)    Excitations inside a 2DM can exchange energy with the environment of 2DMs through near-field resonant energy transfer (NRET). We showed that NRET is very efficient for quantum dots (QDs) deposited onto graphene or TMDs. We also showed that the rate of NRET between QDs and TMDs can be controlled through electrostatic gating of TMDs.

4)    Realistic 2DMs deposited onto realistic substrates are strained. We showed that mechanical strain changes the bandgap of TMDs. We also found that the bandgap of some TMDs transition from direct to indirect at a moderate strain of 2%.

5)    Suspended or substrate-supported 2DMs are always crumpled in the out-of-plane direction. The crumpling strength depends on the nature of the substrate, the type of material boundary, etc… We showed that crumpling profoundly changes the mechanical response of 2D materials. First, the sign of the thermal expansion coefficient was shown to be defined by the crumpling strength, which, in turn, is determined by the strength of 2DM/substrate interaction. Second, crumpling was shown to soften the Young’s modulus of graphene by more than an order of magnitude. 

These results open several avenues for potential applications. The sensitivity of both graphene and TMDs to dielectric screening suggests that it is highly advantageous to embed these materials into a dielectric with large dielectric constant to produce field effect transistors with low carrier scattering. The sensitivity of TMDs to interfacial dielectric screening suggests using these materials as label-free sensors for chemical compounds on its surface. Gate voltage tunable NRET between QDs and TMDs can be utilized for passive display technologies with very low energy consumption. Finally, demonstrated influence of mechanical crumpling on mechanical properties of 2DMs is important to take into account while designing nanoelectromechanical (NEM) devices based on these materials.
